Adventure.name: Occupation Slav
Adventure.nodes: This settlement is now overrun with orc pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The people are grateful to you and offer whatever reward they can.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'Aye, we be pirates, all right. We be ruling the seas, and now we rule the dry lands too. The sea spoke and the sea gets what it wants! Now begone, or be dead.'
'None of yer business, land-lovers. You will know when they wish it. I tire of this jabbering. Come closer, eh? Taste my blade.'
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'

'I tell ya what, this here Slavyan dump doesn't please my captain much. We took some of them little ones to see if they make good pirates one day, but methinks it's not bloody likely. Your man-flesh is pink and mushy. It will not like our waters much. So do a task for me and my men will leave this place be. Or ya can pay us. If you have any pointy-ears, they're worth more to us than any human, so we'll buy 'em.'
'Oh, right, you already failed to do what we asked. Well, I guess you pay or bugger off.'

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

'So you know my paternal legacy. How interesting. I was always told that one day a chosen of the gods will come to claim this and that I should heed their claim. But that was then, and this is now. Pay me, and the piece is yours.'

'My piece comes from my ancestor, Nemoslav, who was a famed inventor and explorer. It was said he delved so deep into the seas, he met the gods themselves there. Gosk's Might is said to unlock the sea's greatest power. Others say it is a treasure sunken many millennia ago, waiting for the right person to claim it.'

'My grandfather tried, his father before him, and my own dad dabbled in it for a time. They all perished in the end, poor, wretched, and crazy. No, it is not for me. I am a scoundrel, sure, but I believe this map was meant for another. You, perhaps, for the right price.'
'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece -- that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'Oh, afraid not. I am only here visiting. The blue orc pirates have taken this village, so it is them you must speak to or kill. I care not. My business here is done. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Tell you what, I'll be camping not far from here for a time. Come and pay when you are ready, but the price is now 10,000.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You defeat Nemoslav and get another map piece.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'
They take the elf and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.
They take the goods and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.

'We're interested in capturing some of them green orcs. They be like us, but odd. But they be more used to this land, so not so easy to catch. Bring me some -- whelps be good, easy to train. You do that, and we go.'
While you talked, the pirates ambushed you. You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'Huh? You be testing my patience. Go do what you said, or beat it!'

Adventure.name: Pirate attack
Adventure.nodes: You are attacked by pirates!
You defeat the pirates.
You are defeated and your ship looted!
'Ah, all right then, you seem like a decent sort.'
You are beginning to get impatient looks.
'There be no dealin' -- we take what we want off you!'

Adventure.name: Gosks Might 1
Adventure.nodes: You find a piece of what looks like an old treasure map, drawn on human skin. The plunder in question seems to be called Gosk's Might and claims to make any land scurvy into a true sea-faring captain. The writing is odd, ancient, but you can decipher the name of a place called Krakovia University, and you know that there are some ruins called Krak not far from here.

Adventure.name: Gosks Might 2
Adventure.nodes: You find the old Krak ruins, and at first they look the same as always. Abandoned, old, and searched-through many times before. But when you look at the map again, you see it now shows you a drawing of the ruins with a note about a secret entrance.

You find the entrance, but the map does not say how to open it. There are several loose stones that you now know are part of this entrance, likely a mechanism of some sort. But some seem broken, so it may be hard to tackle this. Craft tools and intelligent folk may be of help here.

You break through the door and find yourself in a small, dark chamber. Once you light some torches, you see that the room is dusty and stale and holds only one object, a slab of polished stone with writing on it. The language is very old, so you may not be able to read it all.

The writing is incomplete, possibly by design. It talks of Gosk's Might as the greatest treasure one may find in the sea. Another translation of the same phrase can also mean the greatest threat of the deep seas. There is talk of a map split into four pieces and a final key that must be found before Gosk's treasure can be released. The four map pieces are said to lie in the hands of the four greatest sea captains. There is also a short fable, which may or may not be related.

From the fable you can decipher where the map pieces went: One piece to Eric, who braved the seas in the arms of the sea-beast beauty. He may yet swim the seas, as death dare not claim him. One to Nemoslav, who explored the depths of the seas, but his sons were ever keen to stay on land. One to the jolly fool, the J. Wrobel, who outwitted the gods themselves to gain it, but likely lost it again to another. One to Kastytis, the loyal lover of the queen herself. If the four shall ever unite, she will rise from her slumber and reveal the key to her heart.

Your map has the smell of rum and cigars, and the stains of many libations on it. It likely belonged to the J. Wrobel. So, one piece you may find at sea, one somewhere on land, and the last with this Kastytis. You will likely need to track down more pirates to find more clues.
You have one part of the four. It is likely that you will need to confront more pirates and find some clues before you can locate the other three.

The writing is incomplete, possibly by design. It talks of Gosk's Might as the greatest treasure one may find in the sea. Another translation of the same phrase can also mean the greatest threat of the deep seas. There is talk of a map split into four pieces and a final key that must be found before Gosk's treasure can be released. The four map pieces are said to lie in the hands of the four greatest sea captains. It seems you'll need to hunt down some pirates to find the other pieces. There is also a short fable, which may or may not be related.

The writing is very, very old, so you can read only a bit of it. But it talks of Gosk's Might as the greatest treasure one may find in the sea. There is talk of a map split into four pieces and a final key that must be found before Gosk's treasure can be released. The four map pieces are said to lie in the hands of the four greatest sea captains. It seems you'll need to hunt down some pirates to find the other pieces.
You feel as if this story is one that you should know, one that is a part of yours, and yet, it is at the tip of your tongue, unable to be spoken...
You try brute force, but only cause a minor collapse and injure yourself.

You work out the mechanism, open the door, and find yourself in a small, dark chamber. Once you light some torches, you see that the room is dusty and stale and holds only one object, a slab of polished stone with writing on it. The language is very old, so you may not be able to read it all.
You try your best, but you fail to crack the mechanism. You feel tired from the effort.
You feel as if this story is one that you should know, one that is a part of yours, and yet, it is at the tip of your tongue, unable to be spoken...

Adventure.name: Eric
Adventure.nodes:
You are attacked by pirates! The figurehead of the ship is a jurata, and the crew looks particularly nasty and old. The captain stares at you, and he looks like he should be dead many times over - an unliving, in all likelihood.
This may be Captain Eric, the one holding a piece of the map you seek.

You defeat the pirates, and amongst their bodies you find the captain. He looks old, even ancient, his body all but dried up. He has a locket with a fish scale inside it. You also find another piece of the treasure map on his body.
You are defeated and your ship looted!
'Ah, all right then, ya seem like a decent sort. So what do ya want?'

'Yar, sure ya do, they all do. Still, maybe it is time to part with it. You smell of the gods, that ya do. I might have hated ya lot in the past, but I don't care anymore. I simply want to die. My death is held by my love and she has grown mad. Take it from her and the map is yours.'
'Good, yar, good. Here, another map - this one's to her home. If ya can, leave her be, but if not, kill her fast for me. She be old, she be mad, but she be mine still.'
'How could I? She be mine; I be hers... I cannot. But I know it must be done. We had our time. But we be too old for this world.'

'Ya can? Really? Yes, yes, please end it. Here, the map. And because ya were good to me, I give ya some advice. Be careful what ya look for. Tis treasure, yar. But it is black and cursed and tangled in ugly business. Ugly for ya too, chosen one. Be careful.' He kneels before you and awaits his death in peace. As he does so, his posture becomes less like a pirate's and more regal. His crew follows suit, clearly linked to his fate.

He examines what you already have and speaks: 'That old, rum-smellin' bugger's gone and lost his piece, eh? Ya got that one. Ya have the one from the clever one's offspring too. Yar, now ya must swim the high seas and the mighty Captain Kastytis will find ya, for he'll smell that ya got them three. Be careful now. He's as old as me, cranky as me, and his heart's just as broken - more, perhaps.'

He examines what you already have and speaks: 'That old, rum-smellin' bugger's gone and lost his piece, eh? Ya got that one. Now you must seek on land. The whelps of the clever one, Nemoslav, they were given the map from father to sons, and the sons do not like the sea so much. I hear many of your towns are now run by us pirates. Maybe the sons hide there?'

You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free from its rotting prison. You see immense relief in his tired eyes as he passes, and you feel that some of his energy may linger on those who are able to wield such power.

'Ya can? Really? Yes, yes, please end it. Here, the map. And because ya were good to me, I give ya some advice. Be careful what ya look for. Tis treasure, yar. But it is black and cursed and tangled in ugly business. Ugly for ya too, chosen one. Be careful.' He kneels before you and awaits his death in peace. As he does so, his posture becomes less like a pirate's and more regal. His crew follows suit, clearly linked to his fate.
'You fight us like seamen or beat it and stop jabbering!' They seem to stay back, but they are ready for a fight.

You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free of the curse that held him for so long. Thanks to your divine power, you are able to cleanse him, but he lingers yet. 'I feel I am free to go, and yet, your power... Can I stay with you for a time?'

You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free of the curse that held him for so long. Thanks to your divine power, you are able to cleanse him, but he lingers yet. 'I feel I am free to go, and yet, your power... Can I stay with you for a time?'

You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free from its rotting prison. You see immense relief in his tired eyes as he passes, and you feel that some of his energy may linger on those who are able to wield such power.

You defeat the pirates, and amongst their bodies you find the captain. He looks old, even ancient, his body all but dried up. He has a locket with a fish scale inside it. You also find another piece of the treasure map on his body.

Adventure.name: Call for aid
Adventure.nodes: You receive a letter from the Slavyans: Be you friend or enemy, heed our words! A scourge from the seas came upon us in the night. They plunder and rape and think not of leaving our homes. In the name of the gods, chosen, please come to our aid. We heard tidings from other villages. The spirit talkers have fallen also, and even the ferocious alpha clans. Please, hurry...

Adventure.name: Nemoslav camp
Adventure.nodes: 'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece - that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'My business here is done, so I suppose I shall travel again. The family name must remain alive. And because you were so civil about it all, I shall also impart some of my wisdom upon you and leave you a small gift from me. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You find Nemoslav with an odd band of companions sitting in a campsite. 'Well, hello there again. Ready to pay the fee for the map piece?'
You defeat Nemoslav and his crew and find the piece of the map you were looking for.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'

Adventure.name: Eric spwn
Adventure.nodes: You are attacked by pirates! The figurehead of the ship is a jurata, and the crew looks particularly nasty and old. The captain stares at you, and he looks like he should be dead many times over - an unliving, in all likelihood. This may be Captain Eric, the one holding a piece of the map you seek.

You defeat the pirates, and amongst their bodies you find the captain. He looks old, even ancient, his body all but dried up. He has a locket with a fish scale inside it. You also find another piece of the treasure map on his body.
You are defeated and your ship looted!

'How could I? She be mine; I be hers... I cannot. But I know it must be done. We had our time. But we be too old for this world.'

He's as old as me, cranky as me, and his heart's just as broken - more, perhaps.'

But it is black and cursed and tangled in ugly business. Ugly for ya too, chosen one. Be careful.' You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free from its rotting prison. You see immense relief in his tired eyes as he passes, and you feel that some of his energy may linger on those who are able to wield such power.

You open the way to the unlife and the soul of the poor wretch is finally free of the curse that held him for so long. Thanks to your divine power, you are able to cleanse him, but he lingers yet. 'I feel I am free to go, and yet, your power... Can I stay with you for a time?'

Adventure.name: Kastitys invitation
Adventure.nodes: You receive a letter: 'You have the three, fool. Now you will seek me, and I do not wish to prolong this tedious encounter. I await you on my ship. Come, claim your treasure if you can. -- Kastytis'

Adventure.name: Kastitys
Adventure.nodes: When you approach Kastytis's ship, a dark storm consumes both your vessels, as if the gods themselves were watching your meeting. The pirate ship stands silent and seemingly unmanned. Only a single figure stands on the deck, waiting.

The figure, you now realise, is only part human. Most of his body is mutated, twisted and changed, with seaweed, driftwood, shells, and other sea aspects. His eyes look old and tired, and his voice is slow and measured: 'Tell me, chosen, how did you find the first piece?'

You defeat Kastytis and his crew and eventually find the last piece of the map buried deep in the dead man's flesh. You hear the cry of many female voices surround you, and you see swarms of czytlica beneath the surface of the water. They soon disappear, but you feel a chill run down your spine. A new location is marked on your map now, likely the next step in the treasure hunt.

'Ah, Wrobel, yes. So he managed to cheat fate and pass on the map without confronting you. How like him. And so, you met the offspring of Nemoslav, and the poor princeling who gave more than his heart. That one amused my lady most - for the parallels, you see.'
'There is a seal that I need broken. It is on land, so I cannot go. Break it for me and I shall give you the map piece.'

'Ariel? Is that really you? Well, I suppose there is no point lying to you, daughter. Yes, that is my intent. Jurasmat is stronger now, but the seal holds her within her castle. I wish to free her, for she has surely served her sentence by now. Please, convince your friends.'

'It is not my place to say, but she angered the god Perun. You may ask her yourself when you break the seal and come to the castle. Jurasmat holds the final key to the treasure you seek, so you see, doing this deed will help us both.'
'Good. I have marked you. When you reach the shore, any shore, step on land. In time, the place will show itself to you. Come back here when you are done, and I will reveal Jurasmat's castle to you.'
'Good. I have marked you. When you reach the shore, any shore, step on land. In time, the place will show itself to you. Come back here when you are done, and I will reveal Jurasmat's castle to you.'
You fail to defeat Kastytis, and the pirate lord captures one of you! He allows the rest to run away.
'I do not trust them. I do not trust you either, but you need what I have, so trust is not necessary.'

'Eric? You who shares my fate, for the gods like such jests... Well, I suppose there is no point lying to you. Yes, that is my intent. Jurasmat is stronger now, but the seal holds her within her castle. I wish to free her, for she has surely served her sentence by now. Please, convince your friends.'

'Who am I? A sad jest of the gods. A poor sod tricked by love. A loyal servant of the seas. More? Who knows? Kastytis is the name. I do hold the final piece of the map, but I shall not give it to you unless you do me a favour first.'

'I was once a man - human, to be precise. A cliched story followed. I met a girl, she was sad, I sang to her and she loved my voice, so she came back each night to listen. But the gods did not appreciate our love, for the girl was one marked by them - a queen of the seas, soon to be a goddess herself. And so, I was to be taken by the very sea she loved...'

'... Jurasmat used her divine gift to rescue me, but the damned gods were not done, so I was cursed to live as a tree growing on the edge of the sea. My roots swam in the waters, but I was never able to move, to reach her... She in turn was locked in an underwater palace, chained there and changed into a beast to mock her beauty. Her tears turn to amber as she laments our fate... There, this is our story, or at least a part of it.'

'Gosk's Might, the power to rule the seas -- that's the myth, but undoubtedly it is an object of power and likely a treasure to go with it. Gosk, as far as I know, was also an old sea captain or hero, and his city was sunken. It was a bloody obsession for all of us sea folk for centuries. Finally, my lady decided to split the map into four pieces and gave them to four people whom she knew would neither work together nor easily kill each other. Thus, the madness ceased. But it was always foretold that a chosen would put the pieces together one day.'
'She claimed that it was not a treasure she wanted me to find. She would not say more, and I learned not to ask.'

'I do not know. I awoke some decades ago, my body changed, but able to move once more. Perhaps the Darkness broke my chains, or maybe the Shattering of the world released the curse. I care not, for I am free.'
'It will release the last of my curse. It was hidden on land so I could never go there.'
'When I became flesh, the sea became my domain. On land, my flesh turns to wood again.'

'Some are mine; some have other captains; some do listen to the queen still. But it is not within my purview to know the bigger picture. The sea spoke, it called to us sea-fearing folk, told us to come here, to take the land, to take revenge on gods who abandoned us for land-dwellers. And so we come, we take - such is our nature. But I digress too much. You can ask this of the queen once you aid me.'

Adventure.name: Ariel
Adventure.nodes: You find the small reef where you were told Eric's jurata ex-lover dwells. Several sea creatures circle you, and you do spot a jurata watching you closely: 'You smell of him. A smell I longed to be rid of for good. That human fool. So sweet and full of promises, only to break them all...'

You defeat the jurata and her kraken guardian. A pendant on her neck shatters and releases energy. Eric appears before you: 'It is done. I am oddly saddened by this, for she was my love even when she grew malicious and vindictive. My spirit is freed, and I will pass over soon. Here, the map piece you seek.'

He examines what you already have and speaks: 'The awful stench of rum and debauchery suggests to me that you have Wrobel's piece. And I see the legacy of the mighty Nemoslav was passed on too - good. He was a man worth knowing. Now, the last one lies in the hands of one who shares my story, or I his. Kastytis will seek you out now that you hold the other three pieces. I bid thee farewell and give a warning: Kastytis is not like me. His loyalty remains unwavering, whatever he tells you.'

He examines what you already have and speaks: 'The awful stench of rum and debauchery suggests to me that you have Wrobel's piece. Now you must seek on land. The whelps of the clever one, Nemoslav, they were given the map from father to sons, and the sons do not like the sea so much. I hear many of your towns are now run by us pirates. Maybe the sons hide there?'

'As part of her dark humour, it pleased my love to turn me into a pirate simpleton. I was not born one, and now that my essence is free, I can express myself as a prince should. I apologise, friend, but I feel my time draws to an end. Oh, such joy this is, even with the sorrow. I cannot ever repay you.'
You fail and are forced to flee for your lives. The jurata song follows and cuts deep into your souls.

'And what, you thought I would listen to my ex-lover's plea? Hear of how tired he is and how he seeks death? My reasons are my own. Suffice it to say he promised me a different life but failed to deliver. Oh sure, he cried and apologised, swore to live with me on the seas instead. But that was not what I asked for. No, I will not release the fool.' You feel a lot of magic in this place. Those who know how to wield it may be of use here.
'You dabble in dark witchery, no? I heard you can transform people. Can you make me into a land creature, so I may leave the wretched sea?'
'A rodent, how wonderful. Yes, I agree, take me to the land and show me the world, and I shall free the fool for you.'
The jurata does not speak but seems extremely pleased with the change. You've never seen a happier rodent. You see a pendant she once wore on the floor; it cracks and releases energy.

Eric appears before you: 'Now, this is an unexpected turn of events. I am at once overjoyed at my freedom and somewhat worried for the world as you unleash my beloved upon it, even in this diminished form. Still, that is your business. My spirit is freed, and I will pass over soon. Here, the map piece you seek.'

You break the spell and feel the energy released. You hear the angry cry of the jurata, but you are able to sail away quickly. Eric appears before you: 'It is done. And she lives? I... dared not hope for such a turn of events, for she was my love even when she grew malicious and vindictive. Perhaps she will find peace after all. My spirit is freed, and I will pass over soon. Here, the map piece you seek.'

'That is simply beautiful, milady. My heart has not been moved so in such a long, long time. Aye, I am startin' to feel the pirate in me, darn it. But I care not. Arr. Take me with ye, will ye?' The captain reverts to his pirate state, but he seems genuinely interested in joining you now. He clearly has a thing for female demons who sing.
'Wonderful, aye!'
'Woeful shame? Oh well, off I go to the afterlife, then.' His unlife finally lets go, and he begins to fade away.

Adventure.name: BlOrcChildGrowingup
Adventure.nodes: Your blue orc child is ready to become an adult. As such, they will undergo the croppings: a coming-of-age ceremony. But the path is never easy. You must now choose what journey the young one will take before, gods willing, they may return to you as an adult.

You take the kid to the sea and show them how to be a pirate. They must perform difficult tasks to prove they are worthy. (To pursue rare classes, the child will often need a high stat in the appropriate field [exact numbers vary] like strength for warriors, etc. as well as chance. Improving the luck attribute may also help in this.)
The child proved brave and strong enough to be called a pirate.
The child decided that the life of a pirate is bound to the sea. They chose to leave you and become a true pirate.
The child learns well enough, and they are glad to have the chance to become a cooper - a name their pirate family would give to a craftsman.
The child becomes a skilled cooper but is soon recruited by a pirate ship and leaves without a second thought. They told you the call of the sea was too strong.
The trials are successful, and the pirate child grows into a youth under your watchful eye.

The trials for a fighter are tough and dangerous. The child must prove their mantle in the wild and hold their own against stronger challengers. Without another pirate to train them, you are not sure what they can achieve.
By the will of the sea, the child proves a born pirate!
By the will of the sea, the child survives and becomes a boatswain -- the lowest of the ship's crew.
By the will of the sea, the child shows extraordinary courage and wit. Despite their young age, they can now call themselves captain, at least in terms of their skill.
The trials prove too much. The child dies, eaten by a great shark. Perhaps throwing them in with just a fruit knife was a bit much.

By the will of the sea, the child shows extraordinary courage and wit. Despite their young age, they can now call themselves captain. Alas, a true captain has a crew and a ship, so your youth leaves you to become a real pirate.
The child is not good enough to be a pirate. They will be a boatswain from now on.
The trials prove too much and the child dies.
The child decides that the life of a pirate is bound to the sea, and they will never have a chance to advance with land-lovers. They choose to leave you and become a true pirate.
The child emerges from the seas changed, their body grown in mass and mutations. They then heed the call of the sea and disappear.
The child goes into the sea and emerges as a brute!
The child proves brave and clever enough to be called quartermaster.
The child decided that the life of a pirate is bound to the sea. They chose to leave you and become a true pirate.

Adventure.name: The Seal pt1
Adventure.nodes: As you step on the solid ground, you suddenly know where to look for the seal that Kastytis asked you to break.

Adventure.name: The Seal pt 2
Adventure.nodes: You find the stone altar, which you know is the seal that must be broken. There are symbols on it in an ancient language. Candles are lit, despite the winds blowing hard in this place. You feel this is a place of divine origin, but old, very old.

The writing is not only ancient but also divine in origin. The elder races know it, and the zerca are taught it in secret. The symbols roughly translate to: 'By divine decree, this stone is to remain untouched till the end of times.'

This seal is divine in origin, and your goddess was one of two who created it. Your divine connection does not tell you why, or when, there were so many. But you do know that only those who trespassed against the gods directly were punished by curses held by such seals. If you were not chosen, or kin to a chosen, and if Kastytis had not marked you, you would not see it at all.

Your stone shatters and the seal is broken. You feel a gust of wind and then feel saltwater in your mouth, throat, and lungs. You choke and drop to the ground. The chosen feel instinctively that they have angered the divine pantheon.
You fail to break the seal, and you feel divine wrath upon you. This triggers your god connection, and you now remember that such seals must have been formed by the gods themselves.

Adventure.name: Kastitys 2
Adventure.nodes: Kastytis and his crew approach you as soon as you set sail: 'You did it! I thank you, friend. Here, the final piece of the map. By joining it with the others, you shall see the underwater castle of Jurasmat revealed to you. Go, speak to her. I will likely see you there. Be well, but be careful, for you may be chosen, but gods have been known to act in anger...' His ship disappears before you can reply. You now see a spot marked on your assembled map.

Adventure.name: Kastitys 3
Adventure.nodes: Kastytis and his crew approach you as soon as you set sail: 'You did not break it?'

You defeat Kastytis and his crew and eventually find the last piece of the map buried deep in the dead man's flesh. You hear the cry of many female voices surround you, and you see swarms of czytlica beneath the surface of the water. They soon disappear, but you feel a chill run down your spine. A new location is marked on your map now, likely the next step in the treasure hunt.
You fail to defeat Kastytis, and the pirate lord captures one of you! He allows the rest to run away.

Adventure.name: Kastitys Attck
Adventure.nodes: You see Kastytis's ship ahead. He will not speak to you; his crew readies their weapons.

You defeat Kastytis and his crew and eventually find the last piece of the map buried deep in the dead man's flesh. You hear the cry of many female voices surround you, and you see swarms of czytlica beneath the surface of the water. They soon disappear, but you feel a chill run down your spine. A new location is marked on your map now, likely the next step in the treasure hunt.
You fail to defeat Kastytis, and the pirate lord captures one of you! He allows the rest to run away.

Adventure.name: Kastitys 3 spwn
Adventure.nodes:
Kastytis and his crew approach you as soon as you set sail:
'You did not break it?'

You defeat Kastytis and his crew and eventually find the last piece of the map buried deep in the dead man's flesh. You hear the cry of many female voices surround you, and you see swarms of czytlica beneath the surface of the water. They soon disappear, but you feel a chill run down your spine. A new location is marked on your map now, likely the next step in the treasure hunt.
You fail to defeat Kastytis, and the pirate lord captures one of you! He allows the rest to run away.

Adventure.name: Jurasmat
Adventure.nodes: You see the entrance to an underwater castle before you. Several jurata stand guard, and one speaks: 'You hold the map. You may enter and speak to the queen, but you had best bow or we'll have your liver for supper!'

You enter the castle. The sea water is all around you, yet it does not touch you and you can walk and breathe with ease here. You reach the throne room, where Jurasmat awaits. She sits upon a throne made of seashells, but you also see thin, purple lines growing out of the floor and into her body, as if they were chains. She speaks: 'So you have the map and now wish to have the key to Gosk's treasure?'
'And yet, you have murdered my loyal friend, Kastytis. An odd way of showing that you'd like my favour, no? My daughters yearn for blood to avenge their father. Should I not give it to them?'

'Oh my, I am trembling with anticipation, although I did expect more decorum from the new divine pup. Then again, those old, rotten bastards never could see true potential. Only lapdogs were rewarded... Well, then, time to break their toy!' You see the sea water swirl around her and a purple light shining from her, likely the source of the immense power you sense.
You beat Jurasmat and she lies before you in submission: 'What now, chosen? A final blow to end my misery, or will you spare me?'

'The heartfelt answer would be obvious, no? He was my long-lost lover, soulmate, all that. That is the story he told, and believed... poor soul. I did love him, yes. And he was loyal, the father of my daughters. A good man. A wasted life. First the gods, then me, now you... how sad.'

'The songs say I fell in love with a sweet mortal, Perun got jealous and tried to kill him, then I heroically saved his life. I was punished, chained to this castle, changed into a beast, and my tears of amber fall every night for my lost love...'

'I was fascinated by Kastytis - loved him, even. But I was a daughter of the sea, a queen! Perun was not my lover, he was my mentor, teaching me to become a goddess. I suppose I did allow my heart to stray, but it was love that I held for the fleeting beauty of the mortal man - his pure song, his naive heart. I yearned for a moment of mortality before I gave it away for good...'

'But Perun got angry with me for wasting time. He said I was not ready for the responsibility, that I had forsaken my duties as his apprentice for mortal pleasure. He cast his thunder upon the sea, just as Kastytis was on a boat.'

She looks uneasy: 'I... He survived, and even stood up to Perun himself for me. The thunder god laughed, turned to me and said that my mortal would perish soon enough, and that perhaps I would be ready for my divine duty once I am free.'

'Not soon after did I hear of Stribog rising up in the ranks. And Kastytis, the fool, he said perhaps it was for the best - and worse yet, for a moment I thought so too. 'He was my weakness, so I used all the power I had to make him everlasting, make him immortal. This way, he would not be my weakness. But the gods are cruel, for my power turned him into a tree, and Mokosh told Perun I would never be worthy to be her daughter! That bitch!'

'I was to be a goddess, but I got distracted. Perun told me Kastytis was my weakness, so I turned my lover into an immortal tree. Mokosh, the bitch, decided my actions were cruel and selfish and forbid me from becoming a goddess. Stribog was raised in my place.'
'Yes, YOU would say that. Those gods of yours are nothing but lies.' She looks at you with resentment but does not speak further.

You kill Jurasmat, and her jurata daughters utter a deep cry that shakes the foundations of the underwater castle. You also see Kastytis trying to run towards you, his face twisted in pain. But before he can reach you, his body turns back into a tree - a dead tree now, mere driftwood. You manage to take a necklace that you know is the key to your map's treasure before you are forced to run back to your ship.

She bows her head, but you see hatred in her eyes. She takes a moment to slither away into the sea, then, from the waters, she throws you the key to the map's treasure and points at the throne: 'The key, and whatever spoils you can take from the throne room, are yours, for honour demands it of me. Now leave. You have humiliated me enough, god-child.' She swims away, surrounded by her jurata daughters.

You fail to kill Jurasmat and she takes a life as payment: 'The life of one touched by the divine, yes, this will release me. Here, you played well and did your job, so take the key and go find your treasure. I care little for it.' She throws you the key and swims away.
'He was my love once, but I am more than this, so yes, a deal can be made. Without Kastytis, you can no longer break the seal for me. Instead, I require one life. Give it to me and the key is yours.'
'By the nature of my curse, I will not recall this conversation, so when you return, you will have to choose your actions again, and I may not be so willing to deal...'

'The life of one touched by the divine, yes, this will release me. Here, you played well and did your job, so take the key and go find your treasure. I care little for it.' She throws you the key and swims away.

'He was my love once, but I am more than this, so yes, a deal can be made. Without Kastytis, you can no longer break the seal for me, and I should kill you for this offence. Instead, I require two lives as payment. Give them to me and the key is yours.'

'Yes, you have broken the seal, as my loyal Kastytis asked of you. I am now free. Finally! And that a child of the gods released me - how ironic. Here, the key. It will indeed lead you to Gosk's Might, but because you did me a service, I shall give you a warning. Go there, take your treasure, and do not meddle in our plans. If you do not heed my words, we will meet again in combat, and I wish it not.'

'My Kastytis may have told you some of my tale, but his side of it is, well, naive. I did love him once, and perhaps I do still, but this is not why I am chained here. No. The gods were unjust, cruel, envious. They elevated Stribog, that elemental idiot, over me! They will pay, but you, I may yet spare.'

'The songs say I fell in love with a sweet mortal, Perun got jealous and tried to kill him, then I heroically saved his life. I was punished, chained to this castle, changed into a beast, and my tears of amber fall every night for my lost love...'

'I was fascinated by Kastytis - loved him, even. But I was a daughter of the sea, a queen! Perun was not my lover, he was my mentor, teaching me to become a goddess. I suppose I did allow my heart to stray, but it was love that I held for the fleeting beauty of the mortal man - his pure song, his naive heart. I yearned for a moment of mortality before I gave it away for good...'

'But Perun got angry with me for wasting time. He said I was not ready for the responsibility, that I had forsaken my duties as his apprentice for mortal pleasure. He cast his thunder upon the sea, just as Kastytis was on a boat.'

She looks uneasy: 'I... He survived, and even stood up to Perun himself for me. The thunder god laughed, turned to me and said that my mortal would perish soon enough, and that perhaps I would be ready for my divine duty once I am free.'

'Not soon after did I hear of Stribog rising up in the ranks. And Kastytis, the fool, he said perhaps it was for the best -- and worse yet, for a moment I thought so too. He was my weakness, so I used all the power I had to make him everlasting, make him immortal. That way, he would not be my weakness. But the gods are cruel, for my power turned him into a tree, and Mokosh told Perun I would never be worthy to be her daughter!'

'I was to be a goddess, but I got distracted - or so they assumed. Perun told me that Kastytis was my weakness, so I turned my lover into an immortal tree. Mokosh, the bitch, decided that my actions were cruel and selfish and forbid me from becoming a goddess. And Perun decided I was to be banished and cursed to teach me a lesson. Stribog was raised in my place.'
'Yes, YOU would say that. Those gods of yours are nothing but lies.' She looks at you with resentment but does not speak further.

You kill Jurasmat, and her jurata daughters utter a deep cry that shakes the foundations of the underwater castle. You manage to take a necklace that you know is the key to your map's treasure before you are forced to run back to your ship.

Jurasmat looks defiant at first, but your words and your very presence seem to calm her. Finally, she slumps her shoulders and lets out a long sigh. She looks relieved, free: 'You are right, of course. And I am a young fool, just as I was then. I finally see it. Thank you. I... I cannot forget or forgive, just yet. But I will try. Here, the key to Gosk's Might. He is not a legend; he lives and awaits you. The treasure will release him from his prison. Allow it, and risk your gods destroyed, stop him at your own peril, but at least I will no longer aid his cause. Farewell.' She swims away before you can ask more.

'You mean well, god-child, I am sure, but your words cannot undo centuries of cruel banishment and injustice. Take the key, find Gosk's Might, then leave us to do what we will. Do not get involved and you shall be spared.' She turns and begins to swim away.

'I... I thought the mother was gone, that she gave up earth and water to become fire. But I do feel her within you and I must repent. So yes, a deal can be made. Without Kastytis, you can no longer break the seal for me. Instead, I require one life. Give it to me and the key is yours.'

Jurasmat looks defiant at first, but your words and your very presence seem to calm her. Finally, she slumps her shoulders and lets out a long sigh. She looks relieved, free: 'You are right, of course. And I am a young fool, just as I was then. I finally see it. Thank you. I... I cannot forget or forgive, just yet. But I will try. Here, the key to Gosk's Might. He is not a legend; he lives and awaits you. The treasure will release him from his prison. Allow it, and risk your gods destroyed, stop him at your own peril, but at least I will no longer aid his cause. Farewell.' She swims away before you can ask more.

Jurasmat looks defiant at first, but your words and your very presence seem to calm her. Finally, she slumps her shoulders and lets out a long sigh. She looks relieved, free: 'You are right, of course. And I am a young fool, just as I was then. I finally see it. Thank you. I... I cannot forget or forgive, just yet. But I will try. Here, the key to Gosk's Might. He is not a legend; he lives and awaits you. The treasure will release him from his prison. Allow it, and risk your gods destroyed, stop him at your own peril, but at least I will no longer aid his cause. Farewell.' She swims away before you can ask more.

You enter the castle. The sea water is all around you, yet it does not touch you and you can walk and breathe with ease here. You reach the throne room, where Jurasmat awaits. She sits upon a throne made of seashells, but you also see thin, purple lines growing out of the floor and into her body, as if they were chains. She speaks: 'So you have the map and now wish to have the key to Gosk's treasure?'
'By the nature of my curse, I will not recall this conversation, so when you return, you will have to choose your actions again, and I may not be so willing to deal...'

Adventure.name: Gosks Lair
Adventure.nodes: As you approach an underwater ruin, the treasure map lights up, the writing changes, and it now reads as instructions: 'You stand at the brink of Gosk's Might. Enter at your own peril. Persevere and the might of the sea will reward you. Fail and you shall join the darkness of the ocean's depths.'

You enter a chamber that has two stone doors at its end. Both bear the symbol of Gosk's treasure. One reads: 'The Path of Knowledge' The other: 'The Path of Spirit' You also sense that you are being watched.

One of the walls changes into a thin sheet of water, and behind it, you see a large, disfigured creature, half hidden in the dark depths of the sea. You hear a booming but tired voice: 'So, you have come to claim my treasure. Many have tried before.' He points to the floor, and you now realise it is covered with skeletons and half-decomposed bodies. Were they here all along?

The creature's features change as a flash of anger makes his eyes turn blood red and his crooked mouth twist in disgust: 'And here I thought your master was hiding behind that wall of fiery stupidity. All the planning and plotting, and here you are, a child of hers. And you dare come here to gloat?'

You see images of old: a world on the brink of darkness; the gods uncertain of their safety; the mortals meddling, plotting, and finally assailing the sacred tree. You see Gosk, the creature, but he is not so deformed. He is a creature of the sea, akin to Stribog in his elemental form. Gosk's anger sinks entire islands, and mortals die en masse. He argues that this is needed for the tree to be safe.

Perun, the old god of thunder, fights with Gosk and the sea god beats him, but Mokosh stops them. She is angry - no, sad? She tries to calm Gosk, but his waters cannot be tamed now, for he is wild with rage. Mokosh, the lady of life, commands the water itself to engulf the unruly god. He is stripped of divine power and locked in the deepest depths of the ocean for eternity.

'So, she gave you visions. Of course. No doubt I am a crazed god, bloodthirsty... Did she show you how many mortals perished from the Darkness, how close the world came to an end? No... it matters not. You came here for Gosk's treasure. If you wish to claim my power, go through the door.'

Gosk kneels down before your divine power, and you see the spirit of Mokosh herself approach him. She looks at him with pity and disdain, then she takes the map and the key and destroys them. The spirit disappears.
'Yes, or watcher, perhaps? I cannot attack you from here, but I keep those barriers strong, so I'll enjoy watching you try to break them. Now do get on with it. I am bored.'

As you talk to Gosk, his story seems to unravel. He appears overly eager for you to open the door, and once or twice, he bursts out in anger when you mention your gods. Finally, seeing that you noticed, he says: 'Oh, fine. I need you to break the seals. The map, the key - all my doing. But there is a treasure to be had, so we both win. I shall be free, and you, you will be rewarded!'
Your wits are tested and your will stretched thin, but you persevere and prove yourself worthy. The door stands ajar, and within you see a treasury.

You collect your bounty, and then you feel the structure around you shake, forcing you to retreat back to your ship. Once on board, you see a creature emerge from the sea and laugh: 'Yes, yes! Finally. Centuries in the darkness, with nothing but hatred to keep me alive. And now you, of all things, have let me out. Thank you.'

'I am Gosk, the god of the seas and oceans - or I was, before your petty gods locked me away. I saw the fallacy of man before the tree burned. I sought to cleanse the lands to prevent the tragedy. And for my foresight, I was banished. Well, no more. Now I will sink all your lands so the cosmic tree itself becomes part of MY domain!'

'The light that was held in the core of the earth, it formed part of my chain. When it got free, the chain finally loosened, just enough to give me an opportunity. After that, all I had to do was find a god-chosen who would follow my map and find the treasure.'

'The chain was loosened when the light escaped its prison. It matters not if you put it back in or freed it entirely. I care not. I seek only the purity of the water taking all land. Enough talk - I have much to do. But don't worry, you will have some time to settle your affairs.' (200 turns) He turns from you and swims away.

'I was once a god, but I was banished. It was me who arranged for you to find the map, as I needed your divine connection to break the last seal of my prison. Now that I am out, I shall drown all the lands, so that only MY domain remains. But don't worry, you will have some time to settle your affairs.' (200 turns) He turns from you and swims away.
You fail and are forced out.
'That is something you'll just have to risk, won't you now?'

'What? No, no! You can't. Your treasure!' His cries become muffled by the sea that swallows the chambers as the map is destroyed. You feel your divine connection power up, and from within you comes a great force that strikes the prison and sinks it in the depths of the ocean once more. You know with absolute certainty that you have averted another catastrophe and proved yourself a true chosen of the gods.

You see Jurasmat circle the place in anger. She does not speak to you, but she was clearly in league with Gosk. She does not attack you for now, but you get the feeling that she will not talk to you either.
The gods all speak to you in unison: 'You did well, chosen. Now you may shed your mortal coil and walk the land of Thea in any skin you like. Choose well.'

You enter a chamber that has two stone doors at its end. Both bear the symbol of Gosk's treasure. One reads: 'The Path of Knowledge' The other: 'The Path of Spirit' Gosk is still watching you, but now with the anticipation of his freedom.
'It is true that I am not entirely honest. I am eager for you to open the damned door! I am tired of being a guardian, and you seem like you can do it.'
Brute force proves your strength again! The door stands ajar, and within, you see a treasury.
Through the sheer force of your impeccable will and the mastery of your spirit, you prevail and prove worthy. The door stands ajar, and within, you see a treasury.

'The chain was loosened when the light escaped its prison. It matters not if you put it back in or freed it entirely. I care not. I seek only the purity of the water taking all land. Enough talk - I have much to do. But don't worry, you will have some time to settle your affairs.' (200 turns) He turns from you and swims away.
You approach the place where you know the treasure lies but feel an invisible barrier in your way. You can pass it only with your chosen present.

You see Gosk in his humanoid form sitting with Perun and Mokosh by the cosmic tree. They argue, with visions of lands sunken as revenge for humanity's folly and for the Darkness that nearly destroyed the gods. Then you see Gosk in prison, deformed, angry, and forgotten.

'Does it matter to you so much? When I was locked in here for eternity, I changed, became more demon than god. I am now bound by demon laws too. As such, be it by fate or another divine jest, I became the guardian of this treasure and I am bound to honour the rules. They who bring together the four pieces of the map and reclaim the key have proven worthy, and thus I must allow you to go through the test and claim the treasure.'

'What? No, no! You can't. Your treasure!' His cries become muffled by the sea that swallows the chambers as the map is destroyed. You feel your divine connection power up, and from within you comes a great force that strikes the prison and sinks it in the depths of the ocean once more. You know with absolute certainty that you have averted another catastrophe and proved yourself a true chosen of the gods.
Gosk laughs in your face: 'Oh please, spare me. Now, do you want my treasure or not?'

Adventure.name: Sea Thing
Adventure.nodes: You come across a small swamp, and you would walk past it were it not for the odd noises. You hear earthy groans and squishy sounds, and feel the shaking of the earth beneath your feet.

You see the swamp turned inside out as two muddy figures battle. An enraged swamp troll is wrestling with an equally large creature, similarly moulded from the earth, or maybe sand. The creature is covered with seaweed and aquatic debris.
The swamp troll turns to you: 'You help me? Why?'
'Oh, a reward, yes. Here, all I have to give. My friend will go with you.'
'They come from the saltwater. They come and claim MY home. When they do, my swamp dies. Now I must go heal my swamp. I thank you.'
You are badly beaten and forced to flee.
The sea thing stares at you. It seems unsure whether to attack you now. 'You leave the swamp to me now?'
You kill it. The swamp is very quiet now.
'Good. I take the swamp, make it salty. You leave now.'
'The sea tells me to come to land and take the waters so they may become sea. Now leave me be, land thing.'
It looks at you, puzzled.
'Yes. I do as sea asks. Now leave me be. You do your work, I do mine.'

Adventure.name: Blue love
Adventure.nodes: You come across a female orc who seems to be arguing with herself. She is cursing and throwing up her arms. There is also a fairly battered tree stump that likely fell prey to the argument before.

'Bah, how did you sneak up on me?' She makes an aggressive move towards you but stops: '...Apologies. I was distracted and let my guard down. Yet another mark on my tarnished honour...' She spits and looks down in shame.

'I... shamed myself, with a man. A man outside my clan. And there is offspring... And yes, I know what you will say - I am a matriarch, I can bed any male or female I damn well wish. Except for an orc who wields magic, except for an orc from the blue clans, mutated bastards who do not follow our creed...'

'I must kill the man, but more importantly, I must rescue my daughter. She was born a true orc, her blood as green as her grandmother's blood before her. Our line descends from the first matriarch, the Chainbreaker. And this blue fool would have her serve on a ship, as an underling, subservient to some male captain!'

'Ha, you understand, yes! But I know where he ran to, only I cannot afford to follow -- I cannot let my clan know, not yet. I need to prove to them that I can sort this out. If I pay you, will you meet me at the man's hideout and help me reclaim the child?'

'Good, good. A matriarch rarely deals with such matters herself. If you were all orcs, it would be better, but this will work too... Apologies, I am under pressure and talk aloud too much. Here, they are repairing their ship here. Go, get my daughter for me.'

'I know where he ran to, only I cannot afford to follow - I cannot let my clan know, not yet. I need to prove to them that I can sort this out. If I pay you, will you meet me at the man's hideout and help me reclaim the child?'

You come across a small camp. There are three figures sitting by the fire. One looks like an orc male, but his skin is blue -- one of the blue pirates, perhaps. The other two are children, wearing cloaks and sleeping.

The blue orc stands up and walks towards you so as not to wake the children. He speaks quietly, but clearly: 'Well met. At least, I hope so. You do not look like you work for Skullcrasher, but you never know with her - cunning for a female, I'll give her that. I don't suppose you've seen a band of orc trackers on your way here?'

'It is a personal matter, but since my children's lives are at stake... Their mother, you see. She is an orc matriarch. We... well, anyway, we had the children and my boy has magic, so she means to kill him! And she wants my girl to go stay with her clan of crazy bitches. I won't have it. Over my dead body. Which she is trying to achieve... Will you help me be rid of her? I'll pay.'

'I am not sure. The girl will not have an easy life on a blue pirate ship, as we do not allow outsiders to become anything but slaves. But pirating is all about freedom, or it used to be. So I'll just take my crew and go somewhere outside the blue pirate territory, where we can change things.'
You kill the father and grab the children, both of whom were severely injured in the fight because they tried to help their dad. They are crying and kicking you, but they are only children...
As you are about to leave, an orc matriarch with a small band stands in your way. She looks angry: 'Put down my children, now!'
You defeat the matriarch. The children are in hysterics by this point, but they are yours.

'You killed him, and only I was supposed to do that!' She looks angry, but sad at the same time. She growls at you: 'Still, it is done. Now give me the children.' The boy looks up at you in tears and whispers: 'She will kill me, masters, please don't...'
The man defeats you, but luckily he seems more concerned with the children than finishing you off. He takes the young ones and runs away.
'Yes, he has magic and he is male. I am a matriarch. My own offspring cannot dishonour me so. And the girl - stop crying, child, you must learn!'

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'Yes, this is acceptable. We often leave male offspring to their non-orc fathers, so I shall do this. Do not make me regret it!' She grabs the girl forcefully and walks away without looking at the boy again.

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'Yes, this is acceptable. We often leave male offspring to their non-orc fathers, so I shall do this. Do not make me regret it!' She grabs the girl forcefully and walks away without looking at the boy again.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. The orc takes her children away from you, and she drives a dagger through the boy's heart before leaving.
'Good. Here, a reward.' She takes the children and stabs the boy through the heart before departing.
'No, I will do my duty as honour dictates. This does not concern you. Give them to me.'

Adventure.name: Blue love 2
Adventure.nodes: You find the pirate hideout where the matriarch said her daughter is being held. It is small, and you see two children sleeping by the fire.
'So, SHE sent you? Well, you'd best be ready to fight. My children will be free on the seas, not taken by her and her small-minded lot!'
'Bah, the witch. She means for you to take the girl away so she can slaughter me and my boy in peace. Did it not seem odd that a matriarch would send strangers to do this task?'

You kill the pirates and take both children. There is a girl, as you were told, but also a blue orc boy. Both are in hysterics over losing their father. The boy keeps weeping and saying that his mother will kill him.
You see the matriarch emerge from the shadows: 'Hmm, I assumed you would steal her away and leave me to kill the rest. Still, this will do. Hand the whelps to me now.'
'Good. Here, a reward.' She takes the children and stabs the boy through the heart before departing.
'Yes, he has magic and he is male. I am a matriarch. My own offspring cannot dishonour me so. And the girl - stop crying, child, you must learn!'

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'Yes, this is acceptable. We often leave male offspring to their non-orc fathers, so I shall do this. Do not make me regret it!' She grabs the girl forcefully and walks away without looking at the boy again.

She look at you for a while, then speaks:
'Yes, this is acceptable. We often leave male offspring to their non-orc fathers, so I shall do this. Do not make me regret it!'
She grabs the girl forcefully and walks away without looking at the boy again.
'No, I will do my duty as honour dictates. This does not concern you. Give them to me.'
You defeat the matriarch. The children are in hysterics by this point, but they are yours.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. The orc takes her children away from you, and she drives a dagger through the boy's heart before leaving.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. You do not know what became of the child, as the hideout was abandoned when you next returned. You also never saw the matriarch again.
You sneak the child away and her mother appears soon after to claim her: 'Good, good. Now watch her for a bit. I'll be right back.' Before you can say more she disappears into the shadows.

You hear screams from the pirate hideout - amongst them, a man pleading for his son's life. Then the short cry of a child. The girl you hold cries too: 'Oh no, no, you let her find us, she killed pa and brother...' The girl bursts into quiet tears and clenches her little fists.
You run away and the girl is now yours to take care of. She looks scared, but healthy.
The orcs find you, beat you senseless, and take the girl away.
'Good, you are still here. Give her to me.'
'Agreed, she does seem like a snivelling pup. Take her.'
'No, I will make her right. Give her to me, now!'
'Good. Here, a reward.'
You defeat the matriarch. The child is in hysterics by this point, but she is yours.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. The orc takes her child away.
You are discovered, badly beaten, and forced to flee. You do not know what became of the child, as the hideout was abandoned when you next returned. You also never saw the matriarch again.

'He has magic, and the brutes kill off males with magic. And she's a vengeful bitch. She resents the fact that our son will be captain one day; she believes men are not made to rule. My own lot think it of women too, you know. This is why I will take my children away somewhere. Now, will you help me, or will you do her bidding?'
'I... I suppose you are right. The orcs will never give up, and if I keep their attention here, you can run away. But you need to help me beat her first.'

'All right, one will go with you.'
He has tears in his eyes as he hands over one child and urges you to run.

You defeat the matriarch, but she manages to escape. The father approaches you: 'She will keep coming, and her sisters too. Take the children to keep them safe. Raise them well and free, please, and thank you. The sea calls me. I must go.' He departs with tears running down his face. The children are huddled together, but they obey their father well.

You defeat the matriarch, but only barely, and she manages to escape. The father approaches you: 'She will keep coming, and her sisters too. Take one of my children. This way we have a chance. The sea calls me. I must go.' He departs with tears running down his face.
'No, they will stay with me! Now, will you help me kill her?'

You defeat the matriarch, but only barely, and she manages to escape. The father approaches you: 'She will keep coming, and her sisters too. Take one of my children. This way we have a chance. The sea calls me. I must go.' He departs with tears running down his face.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. The orc takes her children away from their dead father, and she drives a dagger through the boy's heart before leaving.
'She is gone, gone for good! I thank you. Now I must go. She has crazy sisters and they will search for us. My man here will serve you now in thanks for the service you did me. Farewell.
'Simple, really - help me kill her! I will take on some of her forces, and you take the others!'

'Yes, as you said, although I see you follow another path now, so I hope you understand it is not the only way. She resents the fact that our son will be captain one day; she believes men are not made to rule. My own lot think it of women too, you know. This is why I will take my children away somewhere. Now, will you help me, or will you do her bidding?'

Adventure.name: Blue love 3
Adventure.nodes: You find the orc matriarch and her bloodtrackers just where the pirate said they'd be. They are camping, but it is likely they've spotted you already.

'So, HE sent you? No doubt spinning tales of my evil ways, eh? Why do you listen to a pirate? They come here and claim our land, and now they want my own daughter to be subservient to them. Did you know they do not allow women to become captains? Disgusting!'

Her face saddens: 'It is the way of my clan; it has been so for centuries. It is not easy, but we live by our code. He will die quickly. Orc men who wield magic fall to darkness more often than not. We cannot risk it.'

You kill the matriarch and her trackers. The father approaches you, carrying his two children: 'You did it, you killed her! I am grateful. But this is far from over. Her bloodline comes from some sort of royalty amongst the orcs, so her sisters will be after us soon enough. Still, you bought us time.'
'I will run, take them far away from here. But, for your service, one of my men will now be loyal to you and hopefully repay my debt one day. Now, I must go. Farewell.'

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'So, you survived, thrived, and seem to live with honour serving the gods of the tree. This is indeed proof. Fine, allow me to take my daughter, and my son is yours. Do not plead for the father. He is as good as dead.'

'I... I suppose you are right. The orcs will never let this go, and with you, my children will have a chance. But I cannot bear to part with both of them. Take my daughter, for life on a pirate ship would be hard for her, with no real rights... Yes, take her.' He hands you his daughter as tears run down his cheeks. The child is bewildered, but obeys her father well.

'No, they are my responsibility, and we will stay together for as long as I live. Be well, friend. But, for your service, one of my men will now be loyal to you and hopefully repay my debt one day. Now, I must go, farewell.'
You are badly beaten and forced to flee. You do not know what became of the children or the father.

'Some choose to abandon their sons in the wilderness, but that is cowardice indeed. Some hide from their duties and hope for the best. Listen, I need to get my daughter. Will you let me get her, or will you stand in my way?'

The matriarch moves out and returns sometime later, covered in blood. She carries her daughter, while one of her men carries the body of her son. She turns to you: 'You did well not to interfere - I respect it. I left a reward for you over there. Now I must go to form a pyre for my son. May the fire ever burn in your soul!'
'No, they are both mine to deal with. Now, stand aside or fight!'

'I... I suppose you are right. The orcs will never let this go, and with you, my children will have a chance. But I cannot bear to part with both of them. Take my son, for he is strong, and will handle the parting better. Please be good to him.' He hands you his son as tears run down his cheeks. The child is bewildered, but obeys his father well.
The matriarch moves out and returns sometime later, covered in blood. She carries the two terrified children and hands you the boy. She does not look back as she walks away with her daughter.

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'Yes, you speak sense and Zorza is one of your goddesses, so I trust you. Fine, allow me to take my daughter, and my son is yours. Do not plead for the father. He is as good as dead.'

She looks at you for a while, then speaks: 'Yes, you speak sense and Zorza is one of your goddesses, so I trust you. Fine, allow me to take my daughter, and my son is yours. Do not plead for the father. He is as good as dead.'

Adventure.name: Gosk
Adventure.nodes: You come to face the vengeful sea god, Gosk! He seems entranced in a ritual, but you know full well he will not go down easily.

You defeat the old god, and his screams of agony create a shock wave that would have destroyed your boat, were it not for divine protection. Gosk's prison opens up once more, and he is sucked into it. You know with absolute certainty that you have averted another catastrophe and proved yourself a true chosen of the gods.
You are defeated and forced to flee for your lives!
The gods all speak to you in unison: 'You did well, chosen. Now you may shed your mortal coil and walk the land of Thea in any skin you like. Choose well.'

You arrive at the point where Gosk was last seen, but in his stead, you see only a great rift in the ocean. Terrible waves of black water flow out from within, and you know they will travel to the lands and sink them all in time... You failed to stop the old god, and soon Thea will become a dark sea, devoid of any land life.
You come to face the vengeful sea god, Gosk! But he is not alone, for Jurasmat swims by his side. He seems entranced in some ritual, but you know full well he will not go down easily.
You approach Gosk, but feel an invisible barrier in your way. You can only pass it with your chosen present.

You come to face the vengeful sea god, Gosk! But he is not alone, for Jurasmat swims by his side. Gosk seems entranced in a ritual, but you know full well he will not go down easily. Fortunately, Szuvarek, the vodnik king you rescued, offers to join you for the fight.
You come to face the vengeful sea god, Gosk! He seems entranced in a ritual, but you know full well he will not go down easily.

Adventure.name: Rocker growing up
Adventure.nodes: Your rocker has aged and the earth calls to it. Who knows what form will emerge from their rock-sleep?

Adventure.name: Lava growing up
Adventure.nodes: Your lava rocker suddenly bursts into flame and melts into the ground. It is time for their reforging.

Adventure.name: Pine growing up
Adventure.nodes: Your pineconette has reached a time of the flowering. It will emerge in its matured form.

Adventure.name: Swamp growing up
Adventure.nodes: Your swamper is looking unwell and has collapsed into a puddle of mud. Could this be natural for their growth?

Adventure.name: Ice growing up
Adventure.nodes: Your icicle has melted away, but it is reforming into something.

Adventure.name: Capturing orc slaves
Adventure.nodes: You find the orc travellers you were sent to attack. They are a small band, and they have children with them, although you know full well even the young ones will stand and fight if attacked.
You defeat the orcs. Only one child remains alive. The others fought till their last breath.
You lost, and the orcs spit on you for taking part in the pirate slave trade. Your relations with the alpha clans suffer greatly.
You meet some of the pirates on your way and they take the child. They promise that they will now leave the town.
You defeat the orcs and manage to capture a child and an adult. The others fought till their last breath.

'You tricked us! You take us like animals. But you won, and you claim the right of alpha, so I must obey the laws. Do not think this will make you a friend to us! The child will go with you - it will serve and learn. But I will not. We return to our clan and reclaim our honour amongst our own kin.'
'So, you come to take us as slaves. I hope you reconsider, for we will die first and kill our own young! Choose your side!'
There is nothing of interest here.

Adventure.name: Occupation Gob
Adventure.nodes: This settlement is now overrun with orc pirates. You do not see the locals, except for the dead ones displayed as examples on the walls. The pirates are enjoying the spoils of their occupation, but they also seem tense.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The people are grateful to you and offer whatever reward they can.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'Aye, we be pirates, all right. We be ruling the seas, and now we rule the dry lands too. The sea spoke and the sea gets what it wants! Now begone, or be dead.'
'None of yer business, land-lovers. You will know when they wish it. I tire of this jabbering. Come closer, eh? Taste my blade.'
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'

'I tell ya what, the little buggers have gone and hidden somewhere. We got their home, we killed many, but the others are just gone, puff... And, well, their shaman sits outside and laughs at us, says we cannot enter their hideout, no pirate can. Or ya can pay us. If ya have any pointy-ears, they're worth more to us than any human, so we'll buy 'em.'
'Oh, right, you already failed to do what we asked. Well, I guess you pay or bugger off.'

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

'So you know my paternal legacy. How interesting. I was always told that one day a chosen of the gods will come to claim this and that I should heed their claim. But that was then, and this is now. Pay me, and the piece is yours.'

'My piece comes from my ancestor, Nemoslav, who was a famed inventor and explorer. It was said he delved so deep into the seas, he met the gods themselves there. Gosk's Might is said to unlock the sea's greatest power. Others say it is a treasure sunken many millennia ago, waiting for the right person to claim it.'

'My grandfather tried, his father before him, and my own dad dabbled in it for a time. They all perished in the end, poor, wretched, and crazy. No, it is not for me. I am a scoundrel, sure, but I believe this map was meant for another. You, perhaps, for the right price.'
'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece -- that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'Oh, afraid not. I am only here visiting. The blue orc pirates have taken this village, so it is them you must speak to or kill. I care not. My business here is done. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Tell ya what, I'll be camping not far from here for a time. Come and pay when yer ready, but the price is now 10,000.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You defeat Nemoslav and get another map piece.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'
They take the elf and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.
They take the goods and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.
'So, you go kill that shaman and let us take them young ones as slaves, and we leave the rest be. They're hiding over there.' He points to a large cave nearby.
While you talked, the pirates ambushed you. You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'Huh? You be testing my patience. Go do what you said, or beat it!'

Adventure.name: Capturing gob slaves
Adventure.nodes: You approach the cave, and the shaman who sits outside speaks: 'So you come to do their dirty deed, eh? They are the enemy; you should not help them. My people are hiding in the spirit world, and I guard them. My wards do not allow the blue orcs in, but I admit, you can enter. So decide whose side you are on, chosen...' You know you can attack here only with magic.

You break through the defences and the goblins reappear in the physical world. The pirates storm the place and take the children as slaves. But they do abandon the adults and the town, just as they promised.
You lost, and the goblins curse you for siding with the pirate slavers. Your relations with the spirit talkers suffer greatly.

The spirit talker boss comes to speak to you: 'You sold our children into slavery. Perhaps you thought you were doing us a favour. Perhaps humans would not mind. But please leave us. We have plans to make. Here is a payment for the... effort. We will not be indebted to the likes of you. Now go.'

'A wise choice -- in fact, one that can help both of us. I understand that in your own way, you were trying to free us from the pirates. Under that assumption, I have a plan. You go tell them you beat us, but instead you take this object of power close to them, then you attack those bastards in the spirit world. Beat them good for us, eh?'

You assault the pirates in the spirit realm, and defeat them. Those who survive run away and abandon the village. The goblins return home and thank you for freeing them. They find an abandoned pirate child and ask you to take care of it.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
There is nothing of interest here.

Adventure.name: Occupation Scav
Adventure.nodes: This settlement is now overrun with orc pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The people are grateful to you and offer whatever reward they can.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'

'I tell ya what, this here scavenger dump doesn't please my captain much. We took some of them little ones to see if they make good pirates one day, but methinks it's not bloody likely. Your man-flesh is pink and mushy. It will not like our waters much. So, do a task for me and my men will leave this place be. Or ya can pay us. If ya have any pointy-ears, they're worth more to us than any human, so we'll buy 'em.'
'Oh, right, you already failed to do what we asked. Well, I guess you pay or bugger off.'
They take the elf and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.
They take the goods and leave as promised. The townspeople are overjoyed with your help.

'We're interested in capturing some of them forest pinecone thingies. Our captain wants to see if we can use them, or maybe he wants to eat one? Dunno. But I'll be damned if I go and catch stupid pinecones, so you do it and we'll leave this dump. The scavengers are all weak and ill and they stink. I am tired of being here.'
'That be our business, land-lover. We rule the seas, aye, but now maybe we be land lords too, eh? Ha ha. Now, come challenge us or be off.'
'Huh? You be testing my patience. Go do what you said, or beat it!'

Adventure.name: Capturing pine slaves
