Adventure.nodes: You track down the grove where you spot a pack of pineconettes. They seem to be unusually agitated, but they are not paying any attention to you.
You defeat the pineconettes. Only one youngling remains alive. The others seem to have perished as soon as you stepped away from their grove.
You lost and are forced to flee the forest.
You meet some of the pirates on your way and they take the child. They promise that they will now leave the town.
You manage to capture some pineconettes without a fight, but you realise that most perish as soon as you leave the grove. One does survive.

The pineconettes do not speak to you, but as you come closer, you are witness to what must be their hatching. You see little pineconettes emerge from the earth, confused and agitated, and older cones trying to catch them and take them away.
There is nothing of interest here.

Adventure.name: Occupation Alpha
Adventure.nodes: You approach the alpha clan town and see it is under siege! Pirates have surrounded the place and there are skirmishes outside the gates. The fight looks bloody. There are dead on both sides, but the pirates have the numbers.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The orcs sing songs of your joint victory!
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'
'I be in a good mood today. We killed many of the green land-lovers, and we have some to take back with us already. You pay us some, and we go.'

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. Some of the locals are chained and forced to work, with others locked up in cages or hung on display as examples. You spot a small camp nearby and the captain is not an orc, but a man. He looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

'So you know my paternal legacy. How interesting. I was always told that one day a chosen of the gods will come to claim this and that I should heed their claim. But that was then, and this is now. Pay me, and the piece is yours.'

'My piece comes from my ancestor, Nemoslav, who was a famed inventor and explorer. It was said he delved so deep into the seas, he met the gods themselves there. Gosk's Might is said to unlock the sea's greatest power. Others say it is a treasure sunken many millennia ago, waiting for the right person to claim it.'

'My grandfather tried, his father before him, and my own dad dabbled in it for a time. They all perished in the end, poor, wretched, and crazy. No, it is not for me. I am a scoundrel, sure, but I believe this map was meant for another. You, perhaps, for the right price.'
'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece -- that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'Oh, afraid not. I am only here visiting. The blue orc pirates have taken this village, so it is them you must speak to or kill. I care not. My business here is done. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Tell ya what, I'll be camping not far from here for a time. Come and pay when yer ready, but the price is now 10,000.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You defeat Nemoslav and get another map piece.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'
They take the elf and leave as promised. But the orcs are furious with you. 'You and your talking, honourless scum, you took our victory! And you sold your own flesh into slavery. Disgusting!'
They take the goods and leave as promised. The orcs are angry at the lost victory, for in their eyes, your deed was honourless. But they do repay you for their people.
'Arr, you drive a hard bargain. It be a hefty price, but if you pay, I sell.'
They take the goods and leave as promised. But the orcs are furious with you. 'You and your talking, honourless scum, you took our victory!'
While you talked, the pirates ambushed you. You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.

Adventure.name: Pirate attack 8
Adventure.nodes: You are attacked by pirates!
You defeat the pirates.
You are defeated and your ship looted!
'Ah, all right then, you seem like a decent sort.'
You are beginning to get impatient looks.
'There be no dealin' - we take what we want off you!'

Adventure.name: Pirate attack 12
Adventure.nodes: You are attacked by pirates!
You defeat the pirates.
You are defeated and your ship looted!
'Ah, all right then, you seem like a decent sort.'
You are beginning to get impatient looks.
'There be no dealin' - we take what we want off you!'

Adventure.name: Call for aid scav
Adventure.nodes: You receive a badly written note that says: 'Filthy buggers gone and got our village taken, you come help us!' You think it is from the scavengers.

Adventure.name: Pirate Shipwreck
Adventure.nodes: You spot a shipwreck. From the markings, it is a blue orc pirate ship.
It looks as if the ship was caught in a storm and hit the rocks, but oddly, you do not see any floating bodies, blood, or signs of sea beasts scavenging the area. The ship is eerily silent and empty.
The ship looks like a cargo vessel, one your people use to transport the spoils of raids, especially slaves. This one is especially large, so it could have been transporting someone or something big.

The ship is empty and quiet. No cobwebs, and not even rats seem to roam the decks. Then you hear a rumbling in the slave cargo hold. Amongst the unnatural racket, you also hear a very quiet song. It is a sad melody, sung by someone who is running out of strength.

You enter the cargo hold and see a lone elf, chained to the wall and barely alive. They are surrounded by a circle made of old runes, likely a protective spell. You also see many rotten bodies of pirates, slaves, and beasts, all torn apart. Amongst them are a few large corpses of dragons, and one of them is looking at you!
You defeat the dragon and rescue the elf slave.

The dragons defeat you, but as you escape the cargo hold, they do not pursue. The fight damaged the elf's protection circle, and the unliving beasts devour their last victim. When they do, they all turn into dust -- perhaps some final curse from the elder child.
They are grateful and pledge to remain with you for the time being.
They are grateful but choose to return to the elven lands.

Adventure.name: Slave ship
Adventure.nodes: You spot a blue orc pirate ship ahead. It seems to be caught in the last of a bad storm.
You sink the ship and then realise it was a slave ship. You may be able to rescue some survivors, but it will not be easy.
You manage to rescue some folk, although some may yet die from their wounds.
Alas, you were too late. The slaves drowned in the cargo hold.
You are defeated and forced to flee and abandon some equipment in payment.
The task is trying, but you manage to haul the ship to safety. The pirates are grateful and hand over some loot as payment for your service.
Your plan fails. The pirate ship is lost to the storm and you barely escape.
They consider your plea, but refuse.
'Bah, I be soft in me old age, but I accept. I be sending you one before we sail. Good winds.'

Adventure.name: Sea loot
Adventure.nodes: You find the debris of an old ship. The cargo looks rotten or otherwise contaminated, but it may still be useful.

Adventure.name: Occupation Slav B
Adventure.nodes: You discover a small settlement - perhaps the Slavyans were rebuilding. But there is not much of it left now. The settlement is overrun with orc pirates. You see locals chained and forced to work, others locked up in cages, and some hung on display as examples.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. Those who survive are grateful, but they pack up and leave these lands, vowing never to return.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.

This settlement is now overrun with pirates. You see locals chained and forced to work, others locked up in cages, and some hung on display as examples. You spot the captain of these pirates, and he is not an orc, but a man. In fact, he looks like a learned man, and on his belt you see a leather tube bearing the symbol of Gosk's Might.

'So you know my paternal legacy. How interesting. I was always told that one day a chosen of the gods will come to claim this and that I should heed their claim. But that was then, and this is now. Pay me, and the piece is yours.'

'My piece comes from my ancestor, Nemoslav, who was a famed inventor and explorer. It was said he delved so deep into the seas, he met the gods themselves there. Gosk's Might is said to unlock the sea's greatest power. Others say it is a treasure sunken many millennia ago, waiting for the right person to claim it.'

'My grandfather tried, his father before him, and my own dad dabbled in it for a time. They all perished in the end, poor, wretched, and crazy. No, it is not for me. I am a scoundrel, sure, but I believe this map was meant for another. You, perhaps, for the right price.'
'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece -- that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'Oh, afraid not. I am only here visiting. The blue orc pirates have taken this village, so it is them you must speak to or kill. I care not. My business here is done. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Tell you what, I'll be camping here for a time, so you can return, but I will likely not remember our little talk.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You defeat Nemoslav and get another map piece.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'
While you talked, the pirates ambushed you. You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.

Adventure.name: Call for aid backup
Adventure.nodes: You receive a letter from the Slavyans: 'Be you friend or enemy, heed our words! A scourge from the seas came upon us in the night. They plunder and rape and think not of leaving our homes. In the name of the gods, chosen, please come to our aid. We heard tidings from other villages. The spirit talkers have fallen also, and who knows who else. Please, hurry...' You are surprised to receive this note, as you destroyed the Slavyan village, as well as the spirit talkers and the alpha clans. Still, maybe it is worth visiting this one.

Adventure.name: Nemoslav Done
Adventure.nodes: You managed to gain the map piece from young Nemoslav. You put the map pieces together and now you are one step closer to Gosk's Might.
You managed to gain the map piece from young Nemoslav. You put the map pieces together and now you are one step closer to Gosk's Might.

Adventure.name: Nemoslav spwn2
Adventure.nodes: You come back to Nemoslav's camp.

'So you know my paternal legacy. How interesting. I was always told that one day a chosen of the gods will come to claim this and that I should heed their claim. But that was then, and this is now. Pay me, and the piece is yours.'

'My piece comes from my ancestor, Nemoslav, who was a famed inventor and explorer. It was said he delved so deep into the seas, he met the gods themselves there. Gosk's Might is said to unlock the sea's greatest power. Others say it is a treasure sunken many millennia ago, waiting for the right person to claim it.'

'My grandfather tried, his father before him, and my own dad dabbled in it for a time. They all perished in the end, poor, wretched, and crazy. No, it is not for me. I am a scoundrel, sure, but I believe this map was meant for another. You, perhaps, for the right price.'
'Well, here you go. Take it and find your destiny on the high seas.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece - that of the unfortunate prince, Eric, so the one you seek now is Kastytis. If you have the three, he will come to you, for he is the general. So swim the seas if you dare, and he will come.'

He takes a look at what you have and speaks: 'You have the drunkard's piece. You found the ruins. Now you must swim the high seas and seek out Eric. He feels the map being drawn together; he will come to you.'

'Oh, afraid not. I am only here visiting. The blue orc pirates have taken this village, so it is them you must speak to or kill. I care not. My business here is done. Farewell, and may the seas treat you well.'
'Oh, well, yes, you did catch my eye there, but now that you say you are a fellow inventor! I have not had my... brain stimulated in too long. Yes, I shall stay.'
'Tell you what, I'll be camping not far from here for a time. Come and pay when you are ready, but the price is now 10,000.'
'Oh, well, yes, you do follow the correct path for my liking. Yes, I shall stay.'
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The people are grateful to you and offer whatever reward they can.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'All right, I shall, you seem like the right sort to try.'
While you talked, the pirates ambushed you. You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
You come back to Nemoslav's camp.

Adventure.name: Occupation Dwarf
Adventure.nodes: You see the dwarf stronghold surrounded by pirate troops. They are camped outside, and they look worn out, hungry, and wounded. The earthbound town is closed but does not look damaged. Still, you will not be able to visit right now.
You defeat the pirates and liberate the settlement. The dwarves are grateful, but they tell you they could have lasted another ten years inside their walls before they would need any outside contact.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'

The pirate captain looks at you, and you see a spark of hope in his tired eyes: 'This be bad for a captain to say, but methinks we will lose this here battle. Truth be told, my boss is just stubborn. So pay us, give us a good elf slave, or do me a favour, and then we be off, honour saved and all.'

They take the elf and leave as promised, but the dwarves are outraged at the sacrifice. They tell you they could have lasted another ten years inside and needed no aid, especially not enslaving an elder child.

The pirates take their payment and leave as promised. In fact, they look relieved as they sail away. The dwarves are grateful, although they tell you they could have lasted another ten years inside their walls before they would need any outside contact.

'Ah, well. The reason we are here is we heard of this mithril the dwarves use. They say their town is carved in the stuff. Methinks it is all bullcrap my boss dreamed up. But a boss is a boss. Give me 100 mithril - I know of a vein nearby, but we do not mine. So, see, this way we both win.'
'That be our business, land-lover. But I admit, this land of stone and metal feels all bad to me, not enough water. Still, them rock folk are said to have treasure, and we be liking treasure, arr!'
'Huh? Go get my 100 mithril! You be testing my patience. Go do what you said, or beat it.'

'Well, I be damned! It be you, as the sea waters are salty! Tell ya what, I had me a promotion after that business, so I be in your debt. I tell my boss this is stupid and we should go. May the sea be kind to ya.' The pirates leave as promised. The dwarves are grateful, although they tell you they could have lasted another ten years inside their walls before they would need any outside contact.

Adventure.name: Occupation Elf
Adventure.nodes: The elf village is closed to visitors. The drawbridges that once led up into the trees are gone, and armed guards watch your every move. You see the heads of many pirates on pikes. An elf guardian informs you coldly: 'None can enter our realm until we track down and rescue our children. They were taken by pirates, but the scoundrels split into so many groups, we cannot chase them all at once. Leave us be.' He walks off.
You kill the pirates and rescue the elf slaves they captured. The Woodlandkin are very grateful for your help, although they claim they could have handled it themselves well enough.
You are badly beaten and forced to flee and abandon some equipment.
'You ain't got anything we want, and if you did we'd just take it off your corpse. Beat it, or come closer and taste our iron!'

You catch the pirates. They look tired and a bit scared as they speak to you: 'I hear ya. Methinks it a terrible idea to anger the pointy-ears so close to their home. But the boss... I be willing to leave, for a price. Pay in goods - give three of your own good-quality folk, how's about it? Or, better yet, you lie to them, tell them we went some other direction, and we give ya one of our own little blue whelps, eh?'
They take the people and leave as promised, but the elves are not too impressed with your willingness to enslave your own kind. Still, they do appreciate that elf lives are worth more than others.
The pirates take their payment and leave the elf slaves they captured. The Woodlandkin are very grateful for your help, although they claim they could have handled it themselves well enough.

'That be our business, land-lover. We rule the seas, aye, but now maybe we be land lords too, eh? Besides, we like ourselves some pointy-eared slaves, that we do. In the old days them lot hunted us and killed us. Now we keep them as pets.'

They give you their own child and leave quickly. You lie to the elves, but alas, they know their lands best and their scouts soon realise your deceit. The Woodlandkin are outraged at your complicity and lies.

Adventure.name: Tavern Gossip
Adventure.nodes: You hear disturbing gossip in the taverns. Apparently the Woodlandkin are under siege from the pirate scallywags! They did not send a call for aid, but then, you would not expect them to.

Adventure.name: Tavern Gossip 2
Adventure.nodes: You hear disturbing gossip in the taverns. Apparently the earthbound are under siege from the pirate scallywags! They did not send a call for aid, but then, you would not expect them to need it for a time. Still, it may be worth a visit.

Adventure.name: The End
Adventure.nodes: You arrive at the point where Gosk was last seen, but in his stead, you see only a great rift in the ocean. Terrible waves of black water flow out from within, and you know they will travel to the lands and sink them all in time... You failed to stop the old god, and soon Thea will become a dark sea, devoid of any land life.
